contents:
Usage Prerequisites You need to have the latest/LTS node and npm versions installed in order to use Victor Hugo.
Next step, clone this repository and run:
npm install  This will take some time and will install all packages necessary to run Victor Hugo and its tasks.
Development While developing your website, use:
npm start  or
gulp server  or for developing your website with hugo server --buildDrafts --buildFuture, use:
npm run start-preview  or
gulp server-preview  Then visit http://localhost:3000/ - or a new browser windows popped-up already - to preview your new website. BrowserSync will automatically reload the CSS or refresh the whole page, when stylesheets or content changes.
Static build To build a static version of the website inside the /dist folder, run:
npm run build  To get a preview of posts or articles not yet published, run:
npm run build-preview  See package.json or the included gulp file for all tasks.
Structure |--site/ // Everything in here will be built with hugo | | | |--content/ // Pages and collections | | | |--data/ // YAML data files with any data for use in examples | | | |--layouts/ // This is where all templates go | | |--partials/ // This is where includes live | | |--index.html // The index page | | | |--static/ // Files in here ends up in the public folder | | |--src/ // Files that will pass through the asset pipeline | |--css/ // CSS files in the root of this folder will end up in /css/... | |--js/ // app.js will be compiled to /app.js with babel | |--scss/ // SCSS files. bootstrap.scss will be processed. | | // Add your custom styles to scr/scss/_custom.scss  Basic Concepts You can read more about Hugo’s template language in their documentation here:
https://gohugo.io/templates/overview/
The most useful page there is the one about the available functions:
https://gohugo.io/templates/functions/
For assets that are completely static and don’t need to go through the asset pipeline, use the site/static folder. Images, font-files, etc, all go there.
Files in the static folder end up in the web root. So a file called site/static/favicon.ico will end up being available as /favicon.ico and so on…
The src/js/app.js file is the entrypoint for webpack and will be built to /dist/app.js.
You can use ES6 and use both relative imports or import libraries from npm.
Any CSS file directly under the src/css/ folder will get compiled with PostCSS Next to /dist/css/{filename}.css. Import statements will be resolved as part of the build.
Environment variables To separate the development and production - aka build - stages, all gulp tasks run with a node environment variable named either development or production.
You can access the environment variable inside the theme files with getenv "NODE_ENV". See the following example for a conditional statement:
{{ if eq (getenv "NODE_ENV") "development" }}In development!{{ end }}  All tasks starting with build set the environment variable to production - the other will set it to development.
title: Installing the Build Tools

contents:
Let’s build a website! Great! Please read each step fully before starting. We’re going to teach you some stuff along the way.
Here’s the steps you’ll take to get Bugo up and running.
 Setup a repository at GitHub Select a starter website Setup Forestry.io CMS  Setup Cloudinary Setup GitHub Pages Add your custom domain(optional) Personalize your website What’s next?  Setup a GitHub Account A repository is like a folder for your website. Your websites’s repository contains all of your project’s files and stores each file’s revision history. This means you’ll always have a backup of every version of every file. Neat huh?
Github is where all your content and code is going to live. Use your email address to sign up for an account. We’re also going to use the same account to sign into Forestry.io in future steps.
You’ll need to decide if you want to keep your website’s code and content private or not. GitHub does charge to keep your repository private, but the cost is nominal and you can have as many private repositories as you like. We recommend keeping your repository private.
Once you’re logged into GitHub, stay logged in. You will be using your login to setup other accounts.
Select a Starter Website We’ve setup a few Bugo starter websites to get you going. Once you’ve decided on a starter, come back here and read the next step before you install your Bugo website.
Browse Bugo Starters
Setup Forestry.io CMS This step activates your content management system. So go back your selected starter website’s page and click Install on Forestry.io button. You’ll need to complete the resulting screens. You can use your existing GitHub account to create your forestry.io account, so feel free to. One less password to remember is always a good thing.
This is going to create a repository for you on GitHub, so when you are prompted to give it an appropriate name. If you’re using a custom domain, use that as your repository name. Something like “your-domain-com”. This will take 5-10 minutes to automatically setup.
Setup Cloudinary Setup GitHub Pages We’re so close.
 Go on over to github.com and sign in, if you’re not already. Navigate to your newly created repository. Create a new branch in your repository called “gh-pages”. Branches are a way to have a different codeset from your “Master” branch. Forestry.io uses this branch to save your rendered website on GitHub Pages. After you’ve created the gh-pages branch, click the settings link. It’s the last tab to the right. Scroll down to the  Add your custom domain
title: Let's build a website

title: For Developers

icon_blocks.text: Use one of our themes, or your own markup and bootstrap to make quickly develop a beautiful responsive markup.
Hugo provides your templating engine and static site generator.
Forestry.io provides a Content Management System for managing your pages and posts.
Github handles all your file management. Your entire website is a Github repository.

blocks.block_text:
## What is Bugo?

Bugo is a framework for a static website generator called Hugo. Developers can use the base Bugo as a boilerplate to building static websites. Content creators and business can use our prefab Websites with themes and get up and running in no time.

blocks.column_1:
## For Content Creators

Use our one click installs to one of our recommended content management solutions. You get a customizable theme and a few suggested pages and sample posts.

[Get Started For Free!](/for-novices/ "Get Started Novices")

### Website Features

Bugo comes with the features you come to expect out of a blogging website.

**Site Search**

Bugo comes with side wide search built in. An index is built by Hugo on every deployment. Because the search is client side it is VERY fast.

**SEO Friendly**

Bugo has structured data, semantic layouts, breadcrumbs & XML sitemaps.

**Taxonomy & Custom Archetypes**

Easily create custom archetypes like profiles or products, for example. Then get those pages organized with Tags & Categories

**Related Pages**

Thought you couldn't have related items with a static site? Relationships are built automatically by Bugo.
blocks.column_2:
## For Developers

You can also use one of our one click installs to get started. Then turn your content creators and developers loose! Coming up to speed is quick and easy.

[Get Started For Free!](/for-professionals/ "Get Started Professionals")

### Build Tool Features

Bugo comes with dev tools that make it fun again.

**Fast Site Building**

Hugo is the fastest static site generator available. No PHP.

**Gulp & BrowserSync**

See your changes almost as soon as you make them.

**SCSS PostCSS & ES6**

Easily create custom archetypes like profiles or products, for example.

**Easy Deployments**

Deployments as easy as pushing your repo and because it's a repository, it's fast.

title: Welcome to Bugio.io. Let's get building!

title: Contact

contents:
Bugo came out of a need to develop websites quickly. Options to build a website with blogging capabilities were limited. Systems like WordPress, Joomla and others require intimate knowledge of them in order to develop anything custom out of the box.
Bugo aims to be a framework that makes it faster and easier to develop, curate and deploy websites with blogging capability. To make this happen you have to think of a website a little differently. Traditionally a website that had blogging capability had to have a web server, database and a content management system (WordPress, Joomla and others). Bugo uses static site generation to cut that list down to a single web server. Everything else is relegated to a service.
So how does that work?  All your code and content are stored in a git repository like GitHub or BitBucket. Developers work on the code locally and push their changes to the repository. Content creators work at with a content management service like Forestry.io or Netlify.com and their content is pushed to the repository. When the content or code is updated a build is triggered and a static site generator builds a static version of the site. The static site is then automatically deployed to the web server.  That’s it.
Media Handling Media can be stored in the repository, but build performance can suffer from a large media library. This can also result in longer deployment times.
Fortunately CMS services like Forestry.io and Netlify.com have thought of this and have integrated with CDNs to make the process of managing Media seamless to the content generator. Developers can still store theme related media in the codebase.
SEO SEO is not a plugin. Traditional websites rely on plugins to enhance the data they present to google. Not necessary with Bugo. Bugo uses all the same stuff built in. Structured Data, Semantic Layouts, Breadcrumbs & XML Sitemaps
Advantages There are several advantages to this approach.
 Speed. Static sites don’t need a database, so they are inherently fast. More Secure. Static sites don’t have most of the vulnerabilities a traditional website. Reduced Sever Loads. Since the server is only serving basic HTML and a limited amount of assets, servers can handle a lot more requests.
title: Introducing Bugo

contents:

title: Forestry.io and Netlify.com

contents:
Got great content to share with the world? Congratulations! You’ve come to right place. Now we’re not going to lie. You will likely learn some new skills. But don’t worry they’re not complicated. We’ll get you most of the way there. Here’s a few things you should know first.
To keep things simple we’ve made some decisions for you. You’ll be using the Forestry.io Content Management System, Cloudinary.com for your Media and GitHub Pages for your hosting.
You’re going to have to setup a few accounts. For that, you’re going to need an email address. Got one? Good. How about a domain? You’ll need one of those too. Once you’ve got both you’re ready to begin.
Speaking of domains, there are too many registrars for us to include detailed instructions when adding a custom domain. Always refer to your registrar’s instructions on adding A records to your domain. This is the hardest thing you will have to do, but most registrars make it pretty easy.
 Try Bugo If you’d try Bugo out before you build a website click the button below. We’ll setup a demo website for you to try out. You’ll be able to create and modify content and media. You can preview the website on Forestry.io, so you can see the resulting pages. This site will not be publicly available. You’ll have to sign up for a free forestry.io account. If decide to try, save your forestry.io account information. You’ll need that later if you decide to build a Bugo website.
Try Bugo on Forestry.io
title: For Content Creators
